posts.text:
As a professional editor, writer and tutor, I empathise with any student who finds it hard writing a critical essay. 

The trick is to make it easier by understanding the psychology behind the actual writing part, and this then makes the process of putting of words on paper (or typing them into a word processor) in a “critical” manner less arduous.

By far the most common cause of “writer’s block” in any field or genre of writing is not knowing why you are committing words to paper in the first place, and hence (as you already suspect with a painful twinge as you write) these words have no hope of ever forming a cohesive whole – let alone a critical whole. This is the equivalent of climbing into a car with no starting point and no destination and then wondering why the journey is unfocussed, shambolic, and seemingly without end.

It is an extremely stressful way to go about achieving effective outcomes in any endeavour: essay writing is no exception.       

In this post, I will eschew all the largely generic, aphoristic stuff they teach you in the writing books (“make sure you have a beginning middle and end”, which is too condescending to be really useful), and tackle the thinking you need to adopt to make the process easier.

I assure you, once you get the psychology behind the process right, and then the process of writing critically itself becomes much easier. 

Step 1. Know your Audience

Any writer in any field or genre who wishes to succeed with his or her writing must “know his or her audience” and write for them – in content, structure and style – if the writer is to effectively engage the reader. This is equally as important in essay writing as it is in any form of writing that is intended to be read by others – though it is an aspect of essay writing that is rarely addressed. 


And this, I’m afraid, means – as much as the radical section of the student population out there might despise the notion – you must actually write stuff your tutor wants to read. 


And what they want to read is critical. No more, no less.


So make sure you pay attention in lectures, gather materials that argue both for and against your tutor’s position, and then you can confidently approach the research phase of your essay with knowledge of what will and won’t “work” to engage your audience (your tutor) and “win” your argument. 

Step 2.  Make your Argument

The core of a good critical essay is to formulate the question (or statement) into an “argument” structure. This is important for three reasons: 1) it is easier to write an essay if you know the perspective from which you are writing; 2) it is easier to structure and hence organise your materials; and 3) you can ensure the “side” you fall down on as regards your argument is consistent with current best practices, theories and research in whatever course or subject you are doing. (See “Step 1. Know Your Audience”.) 

Even if you wish to take a radical stance, and decide not to come down on the currently populist side of the argument (which may work in some cases, depending on your tutor and his or her penchant for radicalism and, indeed, his or her personal perspective on the subject), you still need to ensure you know what the counter-argument is by structuring information in an ordered fashion. (See “Step 3. Structuring Information”.) 

As ever, the rule here with any academic or intellectual endeavour is that you are indeed allowed to think out of the box but you first need to know where the box is!

Step 3. Structuring Information 

As noted in Step 2, you are indeed allowed to think out of the box as regards your essay writing, but you first need to know where the box is.

“Finding the box” is actually simple if you follow this process: take a sheet of paper and draw two columns. Mark column 1 as “For” and column 2 as “Against”. Fill these two columns with quotes/references from authors, papers and journals that consistently back up/refute “your” argument (or counter-argument). 

Then, as you write you merely need to phrase your essay as follows, bearing in mind which side you come down on: 

[INSERT: Author/Researcher from column 1] notes that [INSERT: a concept, point or quote that backs up “your” argument] whereas [INSERT: Author/Researcher from column 2] suggests the opposite. However, when all the evidence is taken into objective account [INSERT: Author/Researcher from column 2] fails to fully rationalise this position with the required academic rigour, whereas [INSERT: Author/Researcher from column 1]’s rationale for his/her position is well documented in [INSERT: articles, sources and researchers that you were given in your course notes you are required to reference].

Done! The cyclical nature of the above “argument” structure can be used for an entire essay or dissertation. Moreover, the style and tone allows you in conjunction with this structure to come down on one side of “your” argument whilst still maintaining academic objectivity.

The bottom line is if you get into the habit of using the above structure it is far easier to keep your own argument straight in your mind, reducing stress and allowing you to produce work confident in the knowledge it is relevant and focused.  

Step 4. Winning the Argument.

Winning your own argument (which in essence is what an essay is all about) should be fairly straightforward, so it is surprising how many essays (the majority) I see where the writer loses his or her own argument in the first sentence. 

To understand how to win an argument, it is worth understanding good debating structure: I spent many years as both a debater and moderator and I can narrow down for you how you can win any argument – even an argument that is factually wrong. 

Ultimately, debates are won by taking at the outset the position of the broadest possible argument; debates are lost by getting bogged down in those pesky things called “details”. 

Thus, we need to codify the broadest possible argument imaginable and then any argument can be won in a written essay by employing it. 

Philosophically, then, in my experience the widest possible, reductive argument in our human experience is:

“There is no such thing as an objective truth; if this is accepted as true, then there is no subjective fact that can refute this position.” 

QED. Argument won – in the first line of the essay!

And if that sounds just a little too hypothetical for, say, your upcoming social work essay titled, “Describe how to best access local support for service users with dementia”, it actually isn’t. The more simple and practical the easy question, the easier it is to set it up as a non-refutable argument due to the level of detail given to you. (The question actually tells you how to win the argument.) 

Thus, the opening line for the above essay topic could not be refuted if written as follows:

“Local support for service users with dementia are best accessed once an assessment of the service user has been undertaken, due to the fact there is a wide array of services available and must be tailored to the specific needs of individual clients in a holistic manner.”

That sentence has no purpose other than to clearly state to your reader that there is no “objective truth” in the matter of “best access” as there are too many variables and contributing factors. Thus, having stated this clearly, there is no single subjective fact or facts (which will comprise the majority of the rest of your essay) that could thereafter refute that statement. Argument won.
posts.title: Four Steps to Writing Critically and Compellingly

posts.text:
It is always worth looking at how great writers structure and articulate their work in order to learn from their successes and sometimes failures. 

D.H.Lawrence is one of the greatest writers of English prose, however his novel Kangaroo is viewed by many as a flawed work. 

In the later stages of the novel, the protagonist, Richard Lovat Somers (who is D.H. Lawrence in all but biographical name, and like him a “ a smallish man, pale-faced, with a dark beard”) grows in his own estimation, until he is laying down the law on how England should have won the war sooner if only Englishmen had been manly enough:

"If men had kept their souls firm and integral through the years, the war would never have come on. If, in the beginning, there had been enough strong, proud souls in England to concentrate the English feeling into stern, fierce, honourable fighting,, the war would never have gone as it went. But England slopped and wobbled, and the tide of horror accumulated."

What does this mean? That the B.E.F. should not have retreated at Mons? It has much more to do with macho fantasy than with any military reality.

The fantasy Australians of the novel all want Lawrence/Somers on their side because he is so rugged and individualistic, but eventually he decides that he is actually too rugged and individualistic to join any side whatsoever. Kangaroo is shot, and Somers/Lawrence goes away, having, it is implied, got a lot of nasty stuff out of his system. It probably worked better as therapy than as a novel.

Considered as a novel, his Kangaroo is a broken-backed unsatisfactory work, but as a human document it is engrossing, revealing the pain of a man whom the war has excluded from the community to which he feels he rightfully belongs.

The first half of the book is a none-too-convincing State-of-Australia novel, by someone who had seen very little of the country. He arrived there by boat on May 4th,1922, spent a few weeks in Western Australia, where he met literary types that he didn’t care for much, then headed East to Sydney, where he seems to have had minimal contact with Australians, speaking with very few of them, but immediately started writing a novel that is set in Sydney and full of conversations. He wrote furiously for two months, and finished before he left Australia on August 11th, having maintained an astonishing rate of over 3000 words a day.

These imaginary conversations tend towards the wish-fulfilling. Somers meets up with manly Australian types who grip his biceps and tell him things like:

“You’re a stranger here. You’re from the old country. You’re different from us. But you’re a man we want, and you’re a man we’ve got to keep. I know it.”

and

“Mr. Somers. You are the man I have been waiting for…”

Typically, the men that Somers talks with and impresses are ex-soldiers; they have intense political projects, in which they want to involve Somers, because they sense his energy and manliness. Mostly the conversation is conducted in big generalities, about the need for change and revolution; Somers rarely comes to specifics of policy, and when he does it is saloon-bar philosophy on the level of:

"if I could I’d just leave the Irish to themselves, as they want, and let them wipe each other out or kiss and make friends as they please.”

More often, though, the talk is about Democracy. In Australia, Somers “for the first time felt himself immersed in real democracy—in spite of all disparity in wealth.” On the whole he approves of this, though there is a feeling that he came to Australia looking for wilderness, and instead found suburbia – miles and miles of bungalows with names like “Wyewurk” and “Torestin”. Somers is “of the common people”, we are often reminded, but he can’t help a snobbery about such things. 

Finally, though, he does not really believe in Democracy, because of the disparity between humans. He believes in leadership and the exercise of power, and this is why he is attracted to the fascist-style leader, Kangaroo, who says things like:

“I want to keep ORDER. I want to remove physical misery as far as possible. That I am sure of. And that you can only do by exerting strong, just POWER from above. There I agree with you.”

“You don’t believe in education?”

“Not much. That is to say, in ninety per cent of the people it is useless. But I do want those ninety per cent none the less to have full, substantial lives: as even slaves had under certain masters and as our people hardly have at all.”

Most of us are only fit to be slaves, apparently, and the book is in two minds about whether we have souls. While Lawrence often reiterates that every human has a precious unique soul – it seems that “your man in the street” somehow has not – “he’s only got a minute share of the collective soul. Soul of his own he has none: and never will have. Just a share in the collective soul, no more.” The contradiction generally boils down to people of whom Lawrence/ Somers approves having souls, and the rest of us not.

As a novel the book is lacking, but as a document from a psychological case study, it is absorbing.
posts.title: D.H.Lawrence: Learning From the Masters

posts.text:
Saul Bellow, the famous Canadian-American author published 14 novels and novellas, winning the Nobel for writing in 1976. He beautifully described the intimacy between the writer and the reader:

"When you open a novel — and I mean of course the real thing — you enter into a state of intimacy with its writer. You hear a voice or, more significantly, an individual tone under the words … It is more musical than verbal, and it is the characteristic signature of a person, of a soul. Such a writer has power over distraction and fragmentation, and out of distressing unrest, even from the edge of chaos, he [or she] can bring unity and carry us into a state of intransitive attention. People hunger for this."

Maria Popova, she of the excellent blog Brain Pickings, describes why Bellows’ advice is relevant for today’s writer:

"How poignant to consider Bellow’s remarks in our age where people seem to “hunger for” cat videos and where the writer’s voice is being increasingly muffled by the “content”-producer’s agenda — and yet, and yet, when we do encounter those ever-rarer “essences” today, those oases of absolute intimacy with another mind, how transcendent our “emotional completeness” then."

As Bellows and Popova make clear, write to connect with your readers. Show them what both you and your characters think and feel and experience. Think of it like this: a blockbuster novel needs tension and suspense and the other ingredients of a good story. Yet when you connect with readers and pour your own unique perspective and temperament into your work, you can connect with readers even without an overwrought plot or the world’s greatest writing style.
posts.title: Why it is Important to Write to Connect

posts.text:
Director Robert Zemeckis and writer Steven Knight seem to have been inspired by nostalgic cries of ‘they don’t make movies like they used to’ anymore from somewhere amidst the older segment of the movie going demographic.

Thank the merciful heavens, then (this imagined demographic might be thinking), that Allied came along!

And thank God that it did – if for no other reason to prove why you shouldn’t – make them like that anymore, that is. (And since this stinker, nobody has, mercifully.)

The irony Zemeckis obviously doesn’t appreciate is that they never did – make them like that.

The problem with making a homage when seen through the rose-tinted prism of nostalgia is that you fail to make a movie that is, of and for its time. Allied feels and looks like a certain spy thriller genre that Hollywood was enamoured of in the 1940’s.

But all the pacing, wit and drama that such a genre implies is strangely because entirely absent.

The stellar cast, Pitt and Cotillard in particular, go through the motions. Pitt in particular looks like he'd rather be almost anywhere else (except a private jet with a free bar surrounded by screaming kids). The central ‘love story’ is about as convincing as wooden six pence piece with Abraham Lincoln’s head stamped with a branding iron on one side – a detriment to the genre that didn’t seem to bother Zemeckis, so intent was he on period detail, crashing planes and sandstorms.

Spectacles he certainly excels at better than picking a story with a narrative that actually delivers any tension.

Ultimately, the film is guilty of the only crime that matters in any entertainment: it fails to entertain. Yawn.

Recommend: For anyone with insomnia or an unquenchable penchant for a parade of handsome OTT nostalgia tropes.
posts.title: Unallied to Story or Plot

posts.text:
Okay, this movie isn't as bad as the trailers they were showing at the time would have had us believe, but it's pretty close: it's the comedic equivalent of drinking battery acid. Caustic. Corrosive. And about as funny as slick banana peels. (Gives you an idea of how really, mesmerizingly bad the trailer is!)

Frankly, two hours of static is a lot funnier than 98% of the 'jokes' in this movie.

And, no, it’s not because I am a ‘misogynist’: that was just director, Paul Feig, and the studio’s vehement retort to anyone that said this film was a knot of cinematic bile (which is anyone with even the faintest affection for the original... or salvageable comedy).

Let’s keep it real: you could have taken any group of middle-of-the-road comedians of any race, creed, gender or ethnicity and it still would have been this disappointment of – okay, alright already – not exactly the monumental proportions fans and critics were fearing. But it's still pretty stodgy comedic fare.


Sure, Kristen Wiig needs to be told she isn’t funny without a much stronger comedic foil (hint, it isn’t Melissa McCarthy: how many unfunny films do we need to prove that?). And, sure, the director and cast responsible for the truly appalling Bridesmaids (remember how we were all supposed to agree how funny that ‘improvised’ disaster was?) was always going to screw this up anyway.

But credit to all involved for a watchable cinematic car wreck that at least doesn't injure those involved too badly: avoid a sequel to this and careers can mostly be saved.

Mostly. The film fails on a critical and irredeemable level: Feig never understood what it was about the source material that audiences loved. At all. In any way shape or form. In fact, judging by this misfire it’s difficult to believe he ever actually watched them.

The original Ghostbusters movies worked because Murray, Ackroyd (whose official comment on this mess is 'no comment'), et al played it straight in a concept that was admittedly OTT bonkers, but went to great pains to get the supernatural stuff ‘right’ in terms of current research on the subject.


In other words, they respected the material as a vehicle for their comedic talents. This ‘remake’ (why oh why make is it a ‘remake’?) has decided to go the pop-culture reference route (‘the power of Patty compels you’) and plays the whole thing like a series of sub-par, disjointed SNL sketches, seemingly sending up the original.

Badly.

Recommended: For anyone who wants to take notes on how not to make a comedy or a remake.
posts.title: Ghostbusters Reboot: Don't Answer The Call

posts.text:
Hoh-oh-oh, boy. Where did it all go so, so wrong? As most online movie reviews pointed out at the time, Suicide Squad was one of the most disappointing big budget blockbuster misfires of 2016.

And that’s a big shame – huge – for any self-respecting DC comic book movie fan or exhausted cinema goer. (Anyone all ‘universed out’ and looking for a movie that is contained in and of itself, and is not merely a feature-length promo for other – hopefully better movies – should stop reading now.) 

The problems with this epic misfire (yes, another one) are legion, with little to be had in the way of entertainment or amusement. (God forbid a DC comic book movie ever actually being fun.)

The story (what there is of it) is predictable tosh, under-utilising both the premise and the potential of the characters – but we’ll get to that in a minute.

From the broader perspective of these billion dollar DC comic book movie turkeys, a question needs to be raised: who the hell is (or should that be “were” as the abominable Justice League seems to have killed the current gloomy incarnation) writing (and approving) the shooting scripts for the DC extended universe films? (Zack Synder, we're looking at you.)  Almost to a fault they are shoddily structured, with narrative holes large enough to drive a tank through, and, in the case of Man of Steel and Batman v Superman endings that are actually inferior – and I am being quite literal here – to mediocre fan fiction.

Of course the answer to that question is probably not as straight forward as critics’ jibes would imply. Suicide Squad never had a single ‘script’ as such as it was originally shot from director David Ayer’s own screenplay, and then someone somewhere in a suit decided it had to be made funnier. Oops.

I touched on this in an earlier Trailer Review: basically, the trailer was cobbled together from the completed footage available at the time, and the fan response to the humour was overwhelming. Then it leaked out that the only jokes the film actually contained were all in the trailer, triggering tens of millions of dollars in reshoots to shoehorn in what, as it now turns out, are a few more, fairly lame attempts at humour that probably made David Ayer’s wife laugh but nobody else.

And this seems to be indicative of the product we got. Ayer’s oeuvre does not exactly suggest a writer/director with a gift for combining the grittily realistic with comic book humour – or anything resembling humour for that matter. He was drafted in off the back of his tough street dramas (End of Watch, Training Day) to maintain what was at the time DC’s Nolan-esque notion of a dark and humourless DC universe (which we are certainly getting).

This dour take on the DC universe, as it turns out, is not – surprise, surprise – what fans wanted. (Gee, no kidding: they had been voicing that polemic since Man of Steel.) So Ayer’s was left in the unhappy predicament of having to turn Suicide Squad from Fury (not exactly a Chuckle Brothers reunion special) into Deadpool in a few short months.

And that went about as well as expected: the evidence is on the screen.

And the story…? Well, that term needs to be used loosely in the case of a film that requires setting up the back stories and character arcs of the six lead characters – characters who you know as much about going into the cinema as you could glean from the garish billboards plastered across every city in the developed world.

Which isn't much.

So how does a writer/director of Ayer’s reputed calibre and standing deal with this admittedly difficult challenge? Why, of course! He throws away the first rule of storytelling, ‘show don’t tell’, and introduces the characters by way of, er, (“Deadpool-lite”) expository cartoon bubbles/comic book panels. Yawn.

Yep, that’s the movie you’re getting people. It doesn’t care how it gets from point A to point B, but it will get there and good film making and storytelling be damned.

To move things forward in this review (a phrase we are betting was never once uttered in a Warner Brothers’ script meeting for the film) we are not going to list each and every character here: look them up on their Wikipedia pages if you feel a more intimate knowledge of their character traits will aid your understanding (it won’t) of what are admittedly fairly boring characters with boring ‘powers’ that barely rate as ‘super’. Captain Boomerang (Jai Courtney in a surprisingly engaging performance – and, yes the actor is actually Australian), for example – here it comes – er, throws boomerangs. That’s about as super as Hawkeye in The Avengers, who, er, shoots arrows. Sigh.

Suffice to say, cramming that much exposition and back story in so early on is confusing.

And, if you aren’t already confused enough thirty minutes in, two more squad members are introduced: Katana (Karen Fukuhara), a samurai warrior whose sword ‘steals souls’, and Slipknot (Adam Beach), the so-called ‘man who can climb anything.’ So, er, Spiderman without any of the cool powers then?

Still, it has to be said, the movie does bring with it a stellar cast, and, as you might have guessed, it is Will Smith’s Deadshot and Margot Robbie’s Harley Quinn who steal the show (regrettably, one not worth stealing). They are the only two characters to be given anything to work with in the way of character and comedic lines, and they do, admittedly, in places – the odd scene and line, don’t get too excited – elevate the uncannily pedestrian material to a level it doesn’t deserve.

As for the plot, it’s pretty much an insane bunch of nonsense that – if (unlike Ayer) you're bothered to think it through – actually undermines the premise of the film. The villain of the piece is (spoilers ... actually, who cares) a squad member! No, way! Way! Knock me over with a titanium-leafed lead feather! 

Enchantress is a possessed archaeologist who defects to the dark(er) side when the government agent responsible for setting up the Suicide Squad sends her in to stop an evil civil calamity unleashed by her demonic brother. Accompanying her is ‘the finest soldier this country ever produced’ Rick Flag (Joel Kinnaman, after Tom Hardy was forced to drop out due to scheduling conflicts with The Revenant; dodged a bullet there, Tom), a square-jawed Captain America (oh, don’t we wish), who is also her love interest.

And, again, sigh. You’d think the film would end right there (if only that were the case) with the Suicide Squad being deemed a pretty bad idea by the military brass overseeing its assemblage; even Flag admits sending in Enchantress was ‘a bad idea.’ No, really? Duh.

But, nope, they are sent in any way to stop the evil villains from carrying out their plot, the mechanics of which entirely comprise building ‘a machine to destroy all of them (humanity, that is)’. Er, yep. That’s it. No explanation. No motivation. Nobody cares. (And Ayer’s wonders why no one went to see this turkey?) 

And, yes, it is as about exciting as it sounds.

From there it is one endlessly boring fight scene after another, all shot in darkness at night in a nameless city: characters we don’t care about fighting villains we’re never really introduced to in a generic city (called ‘Midway City’) for stakes we never really understand.

For all the exposition in this mess of a movie, Ayer’s could have at least pointed us in the direction of where he thought his plot was headed.

As for Jared Leto as The Joker … how can we put this politely? Let’s just say he, ahem, complements the tone and style of the film perfectly: he, like the movie, is wildly vapid and disappointing. For all his boasting about the ‘method acting’ approach (based on, er, what exactly?) he reputedly took to get into the role, he pretty much just delivers the banal eccentricities of an annoying high school prankster, with no depth or wit.

Leto was clearly going the Heath Ledger route; however, what we end up with here is, at best, a ‘Ledger-lite’ performance that doesn’t even ape the best parts of Ledger’s mesmerising portrayal. 

It seems that Oscar nomination for Dallas Buyer’s Club went to Leto's head.

Let’s hope Justice League can drag DC out of this pitiful morass of literally unwatchable superhero movies. 

Recommended: For rabid, craze-blinded DC fans everywhere.
posts.title: Suicide Squad: It’s Not Good To Be This Bad

posts.text:
The misdirection the NYSM2 script would like us to believe is a clever plot device is on par with the improbable onscreen magic tricks the characters conjure up in this insipid attempt to top the original.

Director Louis Leterrier, who helmed the original, at least understood that fun and flash would suffice in an absence of a cogent or remotely plausible plot. Director Jon M. Chu, however, decided that the fun and flash could go and he’d substitute a tepid script instead and see how that played. Not well.


The problem is the plot is so arch, convoluted and curiously unengaging that it is hard to relate to the characters.


Woody Harrelson’s dual turn as Merrit’s evil twin brother, sporting fake buckteeth and a weird perma poodle wig, is as at odds with the tone of the piece as Daniel Radcliffe’s bad guy.


Radcliffe is clearly still on his 'don't call me Harry' bad acting tour de force, and lagging in the memorable parts stakes. His character gets an innovative intro, suggesting we’re in for a treat of a character, then proceeds to degenerate into a stock villain straight out of central casting.

Sigh. Four Horsemen? It sure feels like the apocalypse.

Call Penn & Teller. And a decent director.


Recommended: For diehard fans of the original only.
posts.title: Now You See Me 2 Lacks, Er, Magic

posts.text:
No one at the time could believe it either. Nor were we aware that the trailer was what we can now see with the benefit of hindsight a bitter sweet portent of the humourless schlock to follow.  

Exaggerating? Who’s exaggerating? To list DC comic book movies in order of hilarity would require leaving about the top six places with the disclaimer ‘coming soon to a theatre near you … maybe’.


Out of all DC comic movies, Christopher Nolan’s The Dark Knight Trilogy is the series most directly responsible for ushering in the whole dark and brooding summer blockbuster trend that is currently blighting mainstream cinema.


Because that style and pace worked so well (for The Dark Knight, anyway) – breaking all sorts of box office records on their way to becoming commercial and critical successes (Christian Bale's curiously underwhelming performance aside) – studio execs with dollar signs in their eyes, clamored, 'hell then, give the public more of that'.


Sigh.


And so we were burdened with the Man of Steel semi-misfire and the dour BvS disaster – a film that no one liked, and was about as much fun as watching a small animal slowly and painfully die in peat bog.


The new Justice League trailer, released along with the Wonder Woman trailer (which was also showing signs of developing a sense of humour, along with the Suicide Squad trailer) at the 2016 San Diego Comic-Concruelly hinted at bucking the humdrum and humourless trend.

The trailer is full of pithy one liners that serve the multiple functions of good dialogue by a) setting the tone, b) revealing subtle character traits, c) providing counterpoint to the darker, more dramatic moments, and d) providing an interesting dynamic between the central characters.

And that's in a three minute trailer. Tight writing indeed.


Sure, Zack Snyder is known for delivering great trailers his movies seem either unwilling or unable to live up to, but this time there were (in the end unfounded rumours) that he might just deliver the goods.


Alas, what a cinematic tonic that would have be: whereas The Avengers – even in 2015 – continued to inch ever closer to pantomime humour and cartoonish action, the latest Justice League trailer suggested DC might finally have managed to mine their dark and melancholic tone and premise for the type of funny-because-it’s-poignant-and-true humour that exists at the core of genuine drama.


Now that would have been interesting.


But we saw how that monumental mess turned out.
posts.title: Fun Fact: Justice League Trailer Actually Delivered The Laughs (No, Seriously)

posts.text:
Online movie reviews doing the rounds at the time for this creatively bankrupt franchise were not kind, with the movie review aggregate site, Rotten Tomatoes still sitting on an 11% ‘fresh rating’. Ouch.

This entry must surely represent the nail in the coffin of what has become little more than a gravy train for the increasingly ingratiating vocal talent on display.

It is certainly ironic – and no coincidence – that the funniest character, Scrat, has no lines of dialogue at all.


That is a very telling commentary on a franchise that has become stale, the writing lazy, and the stories (what there is of them) boring, uninspiringly paced and interminably lo-o-o-o-ong (even at 100 minutes).


To be fair, the bulk of the narratives in the preceding entries were as plodding as the lead characters, Manny (the ever-unfunny Ray Roman on autopilot) ... and family… and friends et al are uninspiring.


But Romano is in good company here with his trite comedic shtick – to be fair, it’s not entirely his fault: he has to work with the material he is given (and nine seasons of Everybody Loves Raymond proved he’s not very good at doing that).


And that’s always been the problem with the Ice Age films: the bland, dim-witted characters pretty much rely on the goodwill of the audience to sustain their onscreen antics, which were never exactly enthralling anyway.


And five films in, that goodwill has all but dried up.


Ultimately the whole Manny/Sid/Diego dynamic ends up being about as interesting as a stand-up comedy bill featuring Romano, John Leguizamo and Denis Leary.


And, God, spare us that!


Recommended: For anyone who thinks Scrat deserves his own silent movie.
posts.title: Ice Age: Collision Course With Mediocrity

posts.text:
Roland Emmerich, like tofu, metrosexual fashion and post-modern art, is a distinctly acquired taste.

A disaster porn aficionado, the German director’s ‘epics’ are, invariably (much like post-modern art) rendered on a very broad canvas indeed – broad and violent. If you’re haunted by images of helpless souls running and screaming as their green screen world disintegrates around them for reasons of mendacious weather conditions or the hand of an alien-slash-B-movie-monster, chances are you’ve seen an Emmerich film or two.

It’s been 20 years since Independence Day slayed all comers at the box office; a titan among titans in the heady years of ’90s blockbuster disaster pics. It’s success, like many of its contemporaries, including Deep Impact, Armageddon, Mars Attacks!, Dante’s Peak, Twister and Volcano, did not automatically have money hungry execs screaming 'sequel!' as they do today.
Hence why we had to wait it out for over two decades for a film that, admittedly – if this is to be a brutally honest movie review – no one was particularly asking for.

The film is as strange a beast as any scaly hybrid Chimera in an Emmerich film; but no stranger than any warmed over main dish, defrosted and shoved down the throats of a guileless public two decades beyond its expiry date. A tainted aftertaste, if a guilty pleasure.
Trick is, to enjoy it for what it is, not for what it is not.

In Independence Day: Resurgence, familiar scenes, slightly tweaked, abound: another massive alien ship approaches an intact White House. This time the craft doesn’t destroy it: instead, the ship crawls up and stops just inches away, tipping over a flag a-hoist the building, so close does it park its Darth Vader-lite fender.

And this scene pretty much sets the tone of the film. We get it already: post 9/11, no gratuitous mayhem, no wholesale exploding of public buildings and landmarks. Hollywood’s risk-averse studio system, it seems, is more determined than ever to tone down the violence in certain PC quarters.

Bill Pullman’s character, Thomas J. Whitmore, the former President – he of the gung-ho ‘we will not go quietly into the night’ speech in the original, is now older, confused, and, it seems, sporting a psychic connection to the extra-terrestrials. (Yep, you read that right.)

To cut a (very) long story short, the set up has it that humanity since the first attack has banded together and exploited the alien technology left behind. The headquarters of the new global Earth Space Defence agency is, naturally, situated in the U.S., where the first female President (Sela Ward) has a policy of shoot first and ask questions later.

From there, so far, so familiar. Jeff Goldblum is back as scientist David Levinson, dispensing mildly erudite, how-to-whoop-ET’s-ass consultancy. As with the original, a Top Gun-esque collection of space pilots, this time graced by the likes of Liam Hemsworth (who to thios day still hasn’t figured out how to be a bonafide movie star yet) and Jessie Usher, are deployed to supply the requisite POV shots from inside jerky cockpits.

Star Trek’s, Data’s (yes, he was in the original) kooky Area 51 chief, Dr Brakish Okun (Brent Spiner), wakes up from a long coma to befriend an alien sphere that looks like a disused prop from the 1951 B-movie classic The Day The Earth Stood Still. The characters vex over hieroglyphic-like drawings of what appears to be something you’d see on a Game Boy era ‘Game Over screen.

And the usual hijinks ensue, with the real battle being between the writers who, it seems, never quite won the war as to who the protagonist should be. But, hey, that didn’t stop the original becoming a box office juggernaut.

Worse, for reasons that only a mellowing Emmerich could possibly explain, he decided at some point that what his popcorn film needed was to take a sharp, dark detour down the Christopher Nolan route (have we learned nothing from Batman v  Superman?), and the film has a generally heavier feel to it.

Ultimately, IDR, at least when it drops the self-aware shtick and sticks to po-faced camp, is as fun a ride as you’d expect. It can’t hold a candle to the original but there’s enough combat shenanigans between generic aliens and lesser, Tom Cruise-light mortals, to more or less turn the fun-o-meter up to an 7 out of 10, if you like that sort of thing. (To be fair, as online movie reviews go, this review can't hold a candle to some of the vitriol poured upon upon IDR, which currently scores a lowly 24% at Rotten Tomatoes.)

Recommended: For Jeff Goldblum fans – after all, no one else in the picture stood a chance, including the aliens, of really putting bums on seats.
posts.title: Independence Day: Resurgent And Reheated

posts.text:
The new Wonder Woman trailer was a surprise release at the 2016 San Diego Comic-Con, dividing fans and online movie reviewers alike.

Some online movie reviewers at the time were bemoaning the inclusion of too much action in the trailer, and surmised, therefore, that the movie (which was, to everybody’s surprise, wrapped and in post production) must either be a) non-stop action sacrificing character to the requirements of a big budget, blockbuster movie or b) devoid of enough action, and the trailer has hence given away too much.

Isn’t that always the problem with trailers, though?

Ever since original Wonder Woman helmer, Michelle McClaren, was ousted as director over ‘creative differences’, the chances of too much action diminished significantly, with the studio reportedly wanting a ‘character piece’, and not McClaren’s vision of an epic origins story in the vein of Braveheart.

A character piece? It’s DC not Merchant Ivory.  There were high hopes they’d get that balance right (and they kinda did, more or less).

More worrying was Gal Gadot’s (Fast and the Furious) seeming lack of screen presence and believability in the role (she's easy on the eye, but her acting range seems stuck on 'smouldering'): and now she’s tasked with shouldering her own movie. 

To be honest, to this day the jury’s out on that one.

The upside? At least the tone from what the trailer was showing audiences at the time might – might – have offered some hope of a DC superhero flick that wasn’t as irredeemably bleak and depressing as Man of Steel and Batman V Superman.

And that panned out to be the case, pretty much. 

At the time, DC couldn’t seem to shake off a severe, chronic case of Nolan-itis. Director Patty Jenkins (Monster) at least managed to lighten things up a little, and, though too little too late, the film we got was a passable slice of what might have been.
posts.title: Wonder Woman Comic-Con Trailer Fails To 'Wow'

posts.text:
The real two-part question most online movie reviewers were asking back when this yawn-fest was released was a) who funded this piece of revisionist history, and b) how (and why oh why) did it merit a theatrical release?

We’ll keep this one short. Writer/director, Dinesh D'Souza’s right wing propaganda piece is a slice of curiously stale madness.

Hillary’s America is not necessarily misguided in what it has to say about its subject; it could, however, benefit from toning down the overall ostentatious way it goes about saying it.

In the final analysis, this documentary is really just a grab bag of conspiratorial talking points reshuffled into an order that helps D’Souza make his wildly paranoid points – and history be damned! 

Recommended: For any right wing nuts who think Breitbart isn’t conservative enough.
posts.title: Hillary's America: Right Wing Revisionism

posts.text:
Online movie reviews for the fourth instalment of the Bourne franchise all noted the rot that had begun to set in: the films still boast a great concept and premise but it's a concept that is running out of steam.

All the elements are present and correct: documentary style photography that lends the action in particular an air of frenetic immediacy. Check. Rogue CIA factions out to protect their interests at all costs. Check. Potential love interests for Bourne that director Paul Greengrass turns into cannon fodder with the glee of someone in the know subverting a Bond-esque spy trope. Check.

Etcetera.

The problem is the story: there isn’t one.

Well, not really – and certainly nothing groundbreaking, or anything anyone was clamouring for after a decade's hiatus.

It is a film that is essentially aping its own former greatness.

The Bourne Trilogy worked so well because it had a nifty character and narrative arc that easily fleshed out three taut, suspenseful films. The premise was eloquent in its simplicity: Bourne had amnesia, and gradually over three films he remembered more and more until armed with full knowledge he could confront those who betrayed him.

No more amnesia, no more Bourne films. End of story (you might have thought).

But, oh no. With Jason Bourne (and future instalments, God forbid) they have decided to go a route that is really testing audiences’ patience: Greengrass is now basically using the ‘amnesia’ conceit as an all-encompassing technique to manufacture suspense where none existed or should exist.

In Jason Bourne, the central character now has additional flashbacks (that we had not been privy to in the other three movies), and he then has to come to terms with these as – surprise, surprise – they somehow relate to his original predicament. (I get it – but does Greengrass – it’s a fine line between inspired and contrived.) Huh. Convenient.

If convoluted. Jason Bourne has, essentially, revealed the trick card up the director’s sleeve.

If this is how you’re going to spin out your premise then where will it end: why not have Bourne remembering flashbacks about an alien abduction that the CIA wanted to cover up in order that they could trade human specimens for alien technology, and it is this technology Bourne was really tricked into protecting in Identity, and not American lives, who are now alien chum, and Bourne must now save them with a stolen alien super weapon the CIA had been hiding in Area 51 all along?

See, it's not hard to do, but it's cheating the audience with the very creative conceit that attracted cinema goers in the first place.

Still, admittedly, that premise would have been a better movie than Jason Bourne. 

Recommended: For anyone who likes whiplash via choppy camera work – this film was written by a film editor.
posts.title: Jason Bourne: About As Inspired As The Title

posts.text:
In the mid 1990’s the economic and social makeup of Amsterdam began to transform. The transition to a primarily service oriented city, as opposed to an industrial hub, continued while in the process many factories closed. This inevitable fate also claimed the historic shipyard on the banks of the River IJ in Amsterdam Noord, which is located in the NDSM wharf. The neighbourhood was for a long time considered unsafe, and so the giant building stood abandoned and unoccupied with few daring to venture into the area. 

 

However, in time a small band of intrepid artists relocated to the island and, finding the abandoned shipyard to be a Mecca if open space and filtered light (not to mention easy on their impecunious pockets), decided to set up a collection of informal art studios. As time went on, and word got out, increasingly more artistically inclined squatters arrived and the community thrived and grew, eventually expanding beyond the abandoned shipyard and into the surrounding neighbourhood.

 

With only a tolerance and respect for their artistic history the Dutch could manage, as the area’s population increased and it became safer the city of Amsterdam bought the enormous shipyard and formalised the arrangements. The artists were not kicked out (as they would have been in any other large, expensive metro area in any other European city) but were instead offered formal studio rentals. This encouraged developers to move in and consolidate the areas gentrification with housing, all while leaving the NDSM’s pocket of creativity intact. 

 

Having said that, today’s NDSM – though still artsy – is developing at a rapid pace. Today, the NDSM Wharf has blossomed into a wildly popular cultural hotspot, with the vibrant artist community complemented by an ever-expanding variety of bars and restaurants. This had meant, as it usually does in such cases, hipsters have continued to follow the artists and property prices on the island are heading in a corresponding upward trajectory. 

 

Regardless, the old shipyard building, now thriving and welcoming in all its monumental bulk, is still here. The space comprises over 300 studios that visitors can tour. However, there is a great deal more artwork to be discovered on the island than what is contained in the old shipyard alone. Make sure you mix and mingle with the local artists who are more than happy to show you treasure troves of undiscovered artwork on the island, located in the area of the shipyard. 

 

More than likely, unexpected adventures will take you far off course, but it is precisely that spirit of adventure that drew artists to the island in the first place.

 

Know Before You Go

NDSM is located outside the city centre in the northern part of Amsterdam, but it is easy convenient to reach by Ferry 906m which arrives at the harbour of NDSM in around 14 minutes. It can also be reached with Houthaven Ferry (903) from Amsterdam West.

Travel Tip: Rent a bike at one of the bicycle rentals in the old city of Amsterdam, take the ferry and visit and discover Amsterdam Noord and the post-industrial monuments of the NDSM terrain by bike.
posts.title: Van Gogh Would Approve – Amsterdam, The Netherlands

posts.text:
Walthamstow, a fringe district on London’s northeast borders, was long considered an unremarkable collection of drab gray flats and urine yellow tower blocks. However, times have changed and in line with many areas of London being gentrified, Walthamstow, like Bethnal Green and Shoreditch before it, has seen an influx of curious creatives and millennial hipsters into the area. These two facets of changing Walthamstow collide in the purple explosion of colour and light that is God’s Own Junkyard.

God’s Own Junkyard is located in an old industrial estate, and is curated by Marcus Bracey, who calls defines his creative niche as “neon artist”. It is true, there is neon to spare: stand back and admire a kaleidoscopic jumble of handmade neon signs that resemble a cut price Las Vegas strip – only minus the girls and gaudy facades of hotels and casinos. As for the purpose of God’s Own Junkyard, the place serves – as Bracey explains – many functions: part free art gallery, part dealer and signage recycler for shops and businesses, part prop shop for photo and film locations sought by psychedelically inclined film makers and photographers, part restaurant and café space, and all lucrative customer for whichever local utility company is lucky enough to supply their electricity.

The collection of elaborately lit paraphernalia includes thousands of props, signs and gaudily dressed mannequin figures displayed within this large, open warehouse space. Cheerfully winking emblems destined for avant guard restaurants and hotels gleam from all the free wall space. Stacked high from the raw warehouse floor and dangling like lurid mobiles from the ceiling are totems paying tribute to every form of disreputable entertainment: karaoke, cocktails, rock ‘n’ roll, disco, pinball, casinos. Adding to the decadence, garish displays, inspired by – and in some cases designed for – the Old Soho vice dens (themselves retro throwbacks to more carnal pleasures in more decadent times) neon-accented religious images stand, arms gesturing in unholy tableau. 

Speaking to The Independent newspaper to describe the experience he wants to give visitors, Bracey said: “You stand back and look at it, and that’s what really gives you the kick.”

Know Before You Go

Open to the public only on weekends (exact hours listed on their website), but with places to eat and nearby attractions within easy reach you can make a day or even an evening of it. There is an onsite cafe serving coffee, snacks and alcoholic beverages. There is also a scattering of establishments serving craft beers, cocktails and food. The industrial estate is located around a 15-minute walk from Walthamstow Central Station on the London Victoria and Overground lines. Detailed walking directions can be found here: http://www.godsownjunkyard.co.uk/directions.html
posts.title: This Trip is Psychedelic, Man – London, UK

posts.text:
Although it is full of stunning beaches and views of volcanic mountains, non-essential travel to this tropical wonder is not recommended.

The Sulu Archipelago and the island of Mindanao are specifically noted as dangerous due to terrorist and insurgent activities. Foreign travelers, Filipino-Americans in particular, have been targeted by gangs as victims of kidnappings in the past, and bombings and armed confrontation are also a threat.

Opportunistic crimes, like cons, pickpocketing, and credit card fraud, are also commonly expereienced by tourists.

Before you go
 
Think twice.
posts.title: If Bombings and Kidnappings are Your Thing - The Philippines

posts.text:
You read that right. For all you Potter fans out there, Leadenhall Market, an ornate Central London Victorian marketplace doubled as the setting for Diagon Alley as well as the Leaky Cauldron in the Harry Potter films. 

 

Long before its starring role in the Harry Potter films, the immaculately cobbled floors and ornate 19TH-Century roof, nestled in the historic heart of London’s financial district, already made it a popular destination of locals and tourists alike, and a magical place to spend some time shopping, eating and drinking.

Ranking as one of the oldest covered Victorian markets in London, Leadenhall market has specialised is the sale of fish and meat as far back as far as the mid 14th century, at which time it was an open air market. That all changed in 1881 when the Victorians, hankering to shop for wares out of the indeterminate London weather, constructed the current painted red and green, which then made the market the popular London attraction still popular today.

The market featured several times in the Harry Potter series. Some of the original exterior shots of Diagon Alley – the high-ceilinged and cobblestoned wizarding shopping enclave where Hogwarts students stock up on spell books, wands and other school supplies – show the markets unmistakable architecture.

The Potter reminders can be seen elsewhere: wander down the market’s Bull’s Head Passage and the blue door of a present day opticians (the storefront had been empty at the time of shooting) may look familiar: in Goblet of Fire, it served as the entrance to the Leaky Cauldron. In the films, Diagon Alley is only accessible to witches and wizards through the Leaky Cauldron, which is actually a traditional pub located next to a record store. Muggles beware trying to cross over and usually opt for a pint instead!

Know Before You Go

The interior of the market itself is generally accessible 24/7, and used by locals as a shortcut between surrounding streets. The shop hours, however, vary and sometimes operate limited hours.
posts.title: Harry Potter Shops Here – London, UK

posts.text:
Prestonpans, or Preston, is a small coastal region that lies some 50 miles east of Edinburgh. It currently boasts a vast number of murals painted by members of the local community and guest artists. It also happens to be the site of a historic battle. Here, Charles Edward Stuart suffered a massive defeat in an attempt to regain the monarchy. Dotted around this quaint village are several reminders of this troublesome era. One such example is the Preston Tower.

Dating from the early part of the 17th-century, the township of Preston was granted permission to hold a weekly market and annual fair. As a part of this prestigious distinction, the township was honored with a market cross. This is one of two specifically designed market crosses surviving in Scotland. It’s also the only such structure still in its original location. 
The Preston Cross is constructed of yellow sandstone, octangular in shape, and consists of two doors. At the ground level of the cross resides a circular room that functioned as the town’s jail. Here, convicted criminals would be held for a variety of infractions ranging from public intoxication—to committing slander and not attending church services. 

Above this lockup, connected by a narrow stairway, is a raised platform. From here, proclamations were read out to the gathered townspeople. These would’ve included royal announcements, as well as public decrees. In the center of this podium is a column topped with the symbol of Scotland, a unicorn holding a shield with a red lion.

Know Before You Go

Visible and accessible at all hours of the day. Though there is no entry, the nearby Preston Tower is well worth a visit.
posts.title: Returning Market Value - Preston, Scotland

posts.text:
Thousands of skulls, plus another 21,000 skeletons located just below the main vestry, decorate the walls and ceiling of a Polish church called Kaplica Czaszek: The Chapel of Skulls.

Ii 1776, while America was fighting for independence from England, with the American revolutionary war piling up bodies, bodies were also piling up a in the small Polish town of Czermna, (located a kilometer to the north of Kudowa Zdroj), courtesy of a priest and a local grave digger, but under a very different set of circumstances.

The skulls and bones of over 3,000 people reside (if that’s the right word) within the modest-looking St. Batholomew’s Church. This veritable bone tapestry decorates the ceiling and walls, and the bones are arranged in very specific patterns. The majority are arranged in an eerie, Jolly Roger-style, repeating the crossed bones motif across large sections of walls and ceiling. And that is before we consider the 21,000 skeletons stuffed in the church crypt below, less garishly patterned if not entirely forgotten. 

It is a strange example of some very macabre history indeed, with unclear motivations. Collected by Czech priest Vaclav Tomasek and J. Langer, the local grave digger, it took them around 18 years, from 1776 to 1794, to collect, polish and arrange as many as 24,000 human skeletons, which still pack the church to this day. While most of the skeletons are stacked in a crypt beneath the church, which is around 20-foot deep, the rest are majestically, if morbidly, displayed in what Tomasek viewed as a “sanctuary of silence.”

In terms of raw materials, the grotesque pair had plenty to choose from. The Thirty Years War, the Seven Years War, and countless other skirmishes between Hussite, Catholic and Protestants, Poles, Germans and Czech that bordered the Chapel’s location – to say nothing of the cholera epidemics that regularly killed hundreds – left plenty of mass graves to choose from. Tomasek is rumoured to have found the mass graves by observing where local dogs spent their time digging for bones.

As the priest and grave digger surfaced and cleaned thousands of skeletons, the unholy pair set aside skulls of special interest to be displayed in the church. The skull display can still be viewed today and includes a wide assortment of exhibits: the skulls of the Czermna mayor and his wife, a Tartar warrior’s skull skulls riddled with bullet holes, a syphilitic skull resembled Swiss-cheese, and in pride of place on one wall hangs the skull of a giant. Perhaps most poignantly of all, the skulls of the priest and the grave digger themselves now preside proudly over the Chapel of Skulls they created, never flagging in their morbid fervour long enough to consider the place may one day be their final resting place.

Know Before You Go

The custodians of the Chapel currently do not allow photos inside the vestry or crypt. A trapdoor to the crypt below can be opened to view the other 21,000 skeletons stacked just below. The history of the church is explained in a recording, but is currently only available in Czech, Polish and German.
posts.title: Decorating to Die For – Czermna, Poland

posts.text:
There is an argument that Lake Natron should really come under the heading of "places not to visit" – certainly not if you are into swimming in sodium bicarbonate-free water and nature. (Hint: Neither of them are really represented here.) 

In this terrifying African lake, animals that die are through a natural process of calcification turned into statues. The presence of enormous amounts of sodium bicarbonate ensures dead animals are effectively mummified. For this reason this lake is also known as the ‘Petrifying Lake’ for its ability to turn formerly living animals to stone in a similar process to petrifaction.

It get’s scarier. Because of the high alkaline collection, the lake appears to be an eerie red in colour, especially during the long, hot Tanzanian summer. People have reported this effect as actually glowing at night under the right atmospheric conditions, giving it the weird appearance of magma boiling in a volcano caldera.  

It’s not all bad news. Despite these less-than-favourable conditions, Lake Natron is in fact grazing ground for the Lesser Flamingos that inhabit the area, with many of them calcified for eternity on the shoreline. Fancy a swim? Best choose another lake or risk demise by calcification yourself!

Before you go

The best time to visit the lake is June to August. In order to find the lake safely, fly to Tanzania and book a guided tour of Rift Valley of which the lake is a part.
posts.title: This Lake is Scary – Lake Natron, Tanzania

Happy New Year
