posts.text:
A driver travelling from the UK had his ham sandwiches confiscated by Dutch border guards, who said they were now prohibited under post-Brexit rules.

Video shows an official handling one of the contraband snacks, neatly wrapped in foil, as he asks its owner: "Do you have meat on all the bread or not?"

When he replies he does, he's told: "Yeah, okay, then we take them all."

The driver asks if they can "take off the meat and leave me the bread?" - but is informed that "everything will be confiscated".

"Welcome to the Brexit sir, I'm sorry," says the smirking border official at the Hook of Holland.

People travelling from a non-EU country into the bloc are not allowed to bring meat or dairy products with them.

The rule is in place to guard against the potential spread of animal diseases, such as foot and mouth and swine fever.

Travellers carrying undeclared meat and dairy can be fined or be prosecuted under the rules, which warn that any such products "will be confiscated and destroyed".

A limited amount of fruit, vegetables, honey and fish is allowed.
posts.title: Driver's 'illegal' Ham Sandwiches Seized at Dutch Border Under EU Rules

posts.text:
James Gunn, the writer-director of the box 2014 box office smash, Guardians Of The Galaxy, tweeted the comment, half in jest, when he heard Mike Pence – the dork in question – had given the US Space Force a new name.

The US Vice President announced on the military services first birthday that members of the US Space Force will be called "guardians".

Pence said: "It is my honour, on behalf of the president of the United States, to announce that henceforth the men and women of the United States Space Force will be known as guardians.
"Soldiers, sailors, airmen, Marines and guardians will be defending our nation for generations to come."

The announcement drew a smirking backlash on social media, adding to the ridicule the Space Force has already received for its uniform and logo since its creation in December 2019 by US President Donald Trump.

One Twitter scribe mocked: "It took you a year to come up with a Star Trek logo and a Marvel name? Was your backup the Go-go Gadget Galactics or something?"
posts.title: Guardians Of The Galaxy Director Asks “Can We Sue This Dork?”

posts.text:
Is there life after death? A new Netflix series claims to prove there is. But in doing so, the series relies on a confusing mishmash of fully debunked phenomena alongside matters of faith that aren't in the realm of science, as well as questions that science truly hasn't answered yet.

"Surviving Death" is based on a book of the same name by journalist Leslie Kean. It explores near-death experiences, mediums and séances, ghost-hunting and supposed past-life memories. While the show aims to present "proof" of all of these claims, it confuses its own narrative by offering the same credulity to outright scams as it does to outstanding questions about the process of death. It also treats matters of religious faith as something to prove or disprove. But most religious belief falls outside the realm of science, because it isn't something you can test.

"If you say, 'There's a God; [science] can't do anything with that, but at the moment, you say, 'Ah, but my God, when I pray to them, will move this glass across the table,' that's testable," said Richard Wiseman, a professor of the public understanding of psychology at the University of Hertfordshire in England.

"Surviving Death" marches through an array of paranormal phenomena. The first episode explores near-death experiences, to emotional effect. Interviewees describe harrowing tales of drowning, flatlining after allergic reactions and hemorrhaging in childbirth. All experienced sensations of consciousness during the experience, even though brain waves in the cerebral cortex stop within seconds of losing blood flow. People recalled meeting dead relatives, seeing bright lights or falling into a void of colors; some saw a tunnel, while others recalled seeing doctors trying to resuscitate them.

Near-death experiences have been studied, and there is some evidence that people may experience consciousness when doctors don't expect them to. However, this doesn't necessarily prove that the experiences are mystical in nature; it's also possible that brain activity and consciousness sometimes persist longer than expected after the heart stops. A 2018 study in the journal Frontiers in Psychology found that near-death experiences share a lot of features with how people feel after taking the psychedelic drug N,N-Dimethyltryptamine (DMT). DMT is produced naturally in the mammalian brain, and a 2019 study found that, in rats at least, DMT levels rose during cardiac arrest.

But studying the moment of death in humans is challenging, and no one has conclusively shown the mechanism behind near-death experiences. Dr. Sam Parnia,  director of critical care and resuscitation research at New York University Langone Medical Center, surveyed survivors of cardiac arrest and found that of the 140 interviewees, 46% had a sense of being conscious during the event. Some had memories that appeared to have originated from the intensive care unit (ICU) after the person's heartbeat had been re-established. (Unlike in the movies, cardiac arrest patients are typically unconscious in the hospital for days or weeks after their resuscitation.) For instance, people who reported feeling that hostile beings were torturing them were probably undergoing a common hallucination that occurs when people are being brought out of sedation and having their breathing tubes removed.

But 10% of the people in the study had what sounded like classic near-death experiences, and two recalled seeing or hearing their own resuscitations. One person had an actual verifiable memory — that person reported feeling he was hovering outside his body and accurately described events from his resuscitation, including the use of an automated external defibrillator (AED) and the presence of a bald medical professional who responded to a nurse's call for help. The findings were published in 2014 in the journal Resuscitation.

"They described full details of what is happening to them, and in one of those cases, we managed to confirm [the details], for the first time, as happening during a course of up to 5 minutes," Parnia told Live Science. This was surprising, as the cerebral cortex typically shuts down within 2 to 20 seconds of losing oxygen.

Parnia and his colleagues are now trying to explore this phenomenon in a systematic way. The data haven't been published yet, but the researchers have been bringing a computer into the rooms of patients in cardiac arrest to deliver audio and visual stimulation during resuscitation. The idea, Parnia said, is to test awareness by delivering a random word or set of words as a sort of "prime." If the person survives and regains consciousness, the researchers ask them to name a word in that category, to see if they're more likely than patients not shown a word to come up with the word that was shown as they were flatlining. The researchers are also monitoring the brain activity of patients during the resuscitation process.

In preliminary data presented at the 2019 American Heart Association Resuscitation Science Symposium, 165 patients were tested, 44 survived and 21 were interviewed. Of those 21, four reported memories, including feeling peace and joy, seeing relatives and hearing people in the room talking. No one remembered the visuals presented on the computer screen, but one person recalled the audio.

"What we've learned is that, yes, when we come close to death, we seem to have these transcendental and mystical — whatever you want to call it — experiences…. They're not consistent with delusions; they're not consistent with hallucinations," Parnia said. He said the findings suggest that consciousness may be more complex than experts thought.

"We need to study this objectively," he said.

Parnia was asked to participate in "Surviving Death," he said, but he turned the producers down because the show made no distinction between scientific research on topics such as the recalled experience of death and the pseudoscience of ghosts and mediums.

Regardless of the mechanisms behind near-death experiences, these events clearly can be meaningful. Many people who go through a near-death experience find it transformative. In "Surviving Death," the producers interview a man who flatlined after an allergic reaction to an anesthetic. He had a vision of seeing his deceased father, with whom he'd had a difficult relationship. His father embraced him, which brought the man a sense of enduring peace after the experience.

David Wilde, a psychologist and senior lecturer at Nottingham Trent University in England, has interviewed people who underwent near-death experiences and found that people often report this sort of transformation. One woman interviewed for a paper published by Wilde in 2010 reported that when her heart stopped, she felt that she was in a dark void where she reflected on everything bad she had ever done in her life before hearing a voice telling her not to be too hard on herself. Upon regaining consciousness, she felt she had a chance at a new beginning. She eventually became a counselor and interfaith minister, a path she said she would not have pursued if she hadn't had the near-death experience.
posts.title: Can Science 'Prove' There's an Afterlife? Netflix Documentary Says Yes

posts.text:
The public has been "subjected to too many bad things this year to justify exposing it to bad sex as well", say judges.
Organisers of the Bad Sex In Fiction award have called this year's ceremony off - saying people have suffered enough in 2020.  Set up in 1993 by the Literary Review, the annual prize honours the "most outstandingly awful scene of sexual description in an otherwise good novel".  But as the world remains in the grip of the COVID-19 pandemic, it was felt that an award this year would be one step too far. Previous winners (who are nearly all men, just saying) include Morrissey, Tom Wolfe, Giles Coren, AA Gill and Melvyn Bragg. 

As much as Sky News would like to feature their award-winning work here, it's all perhaps just a bit too sexy for a family audience.

Let's just say that references to a "bulbous salutation" (Morrissey) and the repetition of "slither slither slither slither" (Wolfe) have been involved.
posts.title: People Have Suffered Enough in 2020 Say Bad Sex In Fiction Award Judges

posts.text:
Police appealed to social media users on Saturday to help them track down the two men suspected of robbing a convenience store in Louisa, Virginia, wearing watermelon husks instead of the more traditional stocking masks or balaclavas.

One of the men suspected of donning the watermelon rind disguise has been charged. The other is still at large.

Surveillance cameras caught the would-be outlaws in the act, but their innovative disguises meant they were able to elude authorities, according to the New York Post.

At least they were, until authorities arrested 20-year-old Justin Rogers on suspicion of being complicit in what the Post calledan unfolding “melon-drama.”

According to TMZ, Rogers was booked on three charges:misdemeanour possession of alcohol by an underage person, misdemeanour larceny of alcohol and felony prohibition of wearing a mask/face-covering (presumably organic in origin or otherwise) in public.

According to the Pittsburgh Tribune-Review, police are still on the lookout for a second suspect.

A customer at the convenience store, Candice Wendt, where the robbery occurredsaid the disguises drew afine line between clever and stupid. 

Wendt told WRIC-TV: “I think it’s ridiculous. Innovative but ridiculous- The amount of work that you have to do to actually hollow out a watermelon to stick it on your head, I think, is kind of crazy.”
posts.title: Pair of Melon Heads Rob US Convenience Store

posts.text:
The near-perfect skeleton remains were located in a remote inland area of Antarctica.

A MrMBB333 host told viewers: "What you’re about to see here is intact, very large skeletal remains.

"I would guess this is somewhere in the region of 15 to 20ft. It’s intact."

He added: "I don’t know if this recently thawed and this has been frozen for thousands of years or if this is something new.

"This could be very, very old, going back to prehistoric Antartica.

"Antarctica is a very mysterious place. It could be an old dinosaur. It could be a lot of different things.

"I know there are seals in Antarctica but I don't know how they would get 50 miles inland."
posts.title: Antarctica Mystery: Melting Ice Reveals Remains of huge 'Ancient Creature' on Google Maps

posts.text:
A talented Scottish artist who honed his skills graffitiing buildings in the dead of night has got one of his Christmas wishes - thanks to a painting of Donald Trump.

Tragic O'Hara secured his first international commission after a homemade video of him painting the President was spotted by an American record label on YouTube.

He was asked to design the artwork for the company's Fear and Loathing in Atlanta release after they loved the clip showcasing his work, which he shot in his garage in Kilwinning, Ayrshire.

Steadman, 84, is the illustrator behind Hunter S. Thompson novel Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas, which, in 1998, was made in to a now-cult film starring Johnny Depp and Benicio del Toro and co-written and directed by Terry Gilliam, of Monty Python.

Tragic's 8-minute long video, entitled "How to paint like Ralph Steadman" saw him dripping ink on to paper and using the splotches as the basis for his drawings.

He used calligraphy pens, a shot glass, a dip pen with nibs, water, spray paint, kitchen roll, salt, white spirit and a hairdryer to make the sketches that inspired the American music company to reach out to him.

Tragic told the Daily Record: "I've been a fan of Ralph Steadman's art ever since I read Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas.

"I made this video a while back about Ralph Steadman and his artwork and how much I like it.


"I tried not to do any thinking beforehand - just a big splodge and turn it into something.

"A hip hop record label in Atlanta called Powerseat were putting out a record called Fear and Loathing in Atlanta and they contacted me because they saw the video and commissioned me to make the album cover for them.
posts.title: Scots Artist Lands American Album Cover Gig After YouTubeVvideo of Him Painting Trump

posts.text:
Donald Trump has begun his new venture following his stint in the White House - opening an office that will handle his duties as a former president.

Mr Trump has opened the 'Office of the Former President' in Florida, which will handle his duties in his official capacity as an ex-commander-in-chief, as well as aiming to further his administration's agenda.

"The Office will be responsible for managing President Trump's correspondence, public statements, appearances, and official activities to advance the interests of the United States and to carry on the agenda of the Trump Administration through advocacy, organising, and public activism," an official statement said.

Before leaving the White House, he had tried unsuccessfully to overturn his election loss to Democrat Joe Biden, falsely claiming there had been widespread electoral fraud.

Far from seeking a quiet retirement on the Florida coast, Mr Trump vowed "we will be back" ahead of boarding Air Force One last Wednesday for his final homeward journey to the Sunshine State.

Since his return, Mr Trump has not made any public appearances and has instead stayed at his luxury Mar-a-Lago resort.
posts.title: Donald Trump's 'Office of the Former President' Opens in Florida

posts.text:
The 2,500-year-old debate as to whether the universe is materialistic or idealistic has finally been settled by science: Democritus was wrong – along with most of western science for the past 200 years – and Plato was right. The universe is indeed a literal product of human consciousness, and does not exist independent of our interaction with it. Here are 10 good reasons why your consciousness is likely real, but you almost certainly are not. (Certainly takes the pressure off existence!) 

I am going to dPost my ten best examples from this post over the next ten days under the heading “You are an avatar”. 

I encourage you to do the same, if you think of any I have missed, so your followers and mine can get their minds blown by these amazing new developments in physics, mathematics and philosophy.   

10. Plato v Democritus: Who Would Have Guessed Plato was right?

The very fact that two philosopher’s who lived 2,500 years ago, debating their knowledge of the atomistic nature of the universe (you read that right), could be having a discussion about idealism v materialism makes you wonder if this was not an early example of a glitch in The Matrix. 

Their argument was clear cut: Democritus – famous today for his atomic theory of the universe – argued that the universe was and is, in and of itself, the product of material forces, and required no explanation beyond the testable, physical proof of this existence (http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/democritus/). Plato took the opposite view, stating that he believed the universe was a product of the human consciousness, and without human consciousness the universe would not, and indeed, when we are not looking at and interacting with it, does not exist. Or, in other words, Plato argued, ideas are more fundamental than objects. 

And so the argument raged on, with most western scientists, including Einstein himself, backing 'Team Democritus'. Until now…   

9. The Odds Are Against Our Universe Being The ‘Real’ Universe

In 2003, Oxford philosopher Nick Bostrom – though not the first to propose the idea in theory – is noted for codifying the ‘simulation argument’ into a workable (if some accuse it of being reductive) argument (http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/democritus/). Bostrom basically lays it out like this: one of three possibilities must be true (remember this is an either/or proposition): 

  1. Post-human-level civilisations that develop sufficiently advanced technology to run a simulation of the level and detail seen in the universe in which we inhabit is zero, or

  2. The number of post-human-level civilisations that have lost interest in running ‘ancestor simulations’ once they’ve got the technology is zero, or

  3. Post-human-level civilisations are indeed running ancestor programs, implying the technology required to do so at the level of detail seen in our universe means the programmers could run unlimited numbers of these simulations. Ergo: we are statistically more likely to be in one of the trillions of simulated universes than the ‘real’ universe.  

And he’s a real professor, so he ought to know!

But is there anything to back up Bostrom’s hypothesis? As it happens, the answer is ‘yes’…

8. Increased Computing Power Backs Up Nick Bostrom’s Hypothesis That We Are Not in the “Real Universe”

Anyone who has ever played the tactical game, 'Insurgency' knows that a virtual world indistinguishable from reality is just around the corner – and that is based on the relatively primitive (compared to the time-frame in which it has had to evolve) computing power available to us in our present-day civilisation. 

This needs to be seen in the context of the fact that Moore's law – the famous notion that computing power doubles every 24 months (http://www.mooreslaw.org/) – is as true today as it ever was – thanks to (perhaps ironically) the dawn of quantum computing: Google’s D-Wave having made the leap from 512 to more than a 1000 qubits being an example of this (http://www.wired.com/2015/09/googles-quantum-computer-just-got-a-big-upgrade-1000-qubits/). Is it really so hard to believe a simulation showing the level of detail in ‘our’ universe would be possible to program by our sufficiently technologically advanced, distant descendants?

Even Nick Bostrom did not rule out the notion that simulated realities could exist within simulated realities, and saw this a possible – thought not a prerequisite – ‘optional extra’.

So if we do live in a simulated reality, are there any bugs to give the pre-programmed game away? Look around you, there might just be…

7. Who Says The Simulation We Almost Certainly Live In Is That Good Anyway?

In any artificial simulation you would expect bugs; things the programmer did not quite perfect or have time to perfect, or sub-routines that are simply not needed when we are not aware of them, like your tongue or anus when you’re not using them (https://aeon.co/essays/is-reality-a-computer-simulation-does-it-matter). If we take a look around our universe we tend to find such anomalies: take the event horizon at the centre of a black hole, for example. The event horizon describes the point at which the gravity of an imploded star is so dense that the usual rules of physics do not apply, and indeed space and time cannot even be described at this scale – a scale where they do not technically exist (http://phys.org/news/2015-01-black-holes-space-theory.html).

Considering that the anomaly of gravity itself is best described by the simulation theory as the ‘denser’ concentration of processing power required to ‘build’ complex objects in a digital universe (http://uk.mathworks.com/company/newsletters/articles/improving-simulation-performance-in-simulink.html?requestedDomain=www.mathworks.com), is it any great stretch to think a black hole might be where computational power was insufficient to maintain the digital illusion?      

And if the universe is a digital illusion, then that must mean it’s made of… (the answer might surprise you!)

6. The Universe Is Made Of ‘Quantum Bits’

Just like the bits in a computer, with each bit being represented by either a one or a zero computer (http://cmsw.mit.edu/angles/2015/wp/is-the-universe-actually-a-giant-quantum-computer/). 

If the universe really is a simulation, then we would expect to find that the fundamental nature of the universe is digital – which is exactly what scientists are finding (http://www.smithsonianmag.com/ist/?next=/science/what-universe-real-physics-has-some-mind-bending-answers-180952699/). 

The universe is made up of quantum bits, with the very nature of the physical laws of the universe resembling a quantum computer. 

In the words of Seth Lloyd, professor of mechanical engineering at MIT, 

“Everything in the universe is made of bits. Not chunks of stuff, but chunks of information – ones and zeros. … Atoms and electrons are bits. Atomic collisions are ‘ops’. Machine language is the laws of physics. The universe is a quantum computer” (http://www.wired.com/2006/03/life-the-universe-and-everything/).

And it is not only the reasoning of many mechanical engineers like Lloyd that draw the same conclusion. The famous “Double Slit” experiment demonstrates it in action…

5. The Evidence Is In: The Double Slit Experiment 

No way round the conclusions drawn by this in(?)famous experiment, repeated thousands of times in hundreds of different laboratories around the world, with the exact same outcomes. To keep this experiment simple, imagine a panel on an atomic scale with two slits through which light and matter can be fired from an atomic particle gun, hitting an observation panel on the other side of the slit (L http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/guest-blog/what-does-the-new-double-slit-experiment-actually-show/). The pattern the particles make when fired through these slits can be measured by the formations they make on the observation panel.  

The behaviour these particles show – whether photons, atoms, etc. – when the experiment is being observed and when it is not being observed is what initially baffled scientists, who were sent groping for less intuitive ways to describe the universe (http://www.felderbooks.com/papers/quantum.html). Here’s what’s weird: when the particles are observed they form a ‘band-like’ pattern, conducive to solid particles hitting a solid panel. When they are not observed they form a wavelike pattern, the duality of the results being described as ‘wave-particle duality’. 

The upshot of this experiment became clear: matter only exists as a ‘probability wave’ when not interacting with human consciousness (http://physics.stackexchange.com/questions/9244/light-waves-and-schr%C3%B6dinger-probability-waves). Ergo, ‘reality’ only exists as a probability wave when not interacting with human consciousness, (thus proving Plato’s assertion). 

And what about Einstein? Where does he weight in on all the crazy physics? 

4. Quantum Entanglement: What Einstein Called ‘Spooky Action'  

One of the weirdest particle behaviours observed in modern physics is that described by quantum entanglement, which Einstein – no fan of quantum physics (http://www.realclearscience.com/2011/12/16/why_einstein_hated_quantum_mechanics_244547.html) – dismissed as ‘spooky action at a distance’ (http://www.livescience.com/28550-how-quantum-entanglement-works-infographic.html). In a nutshell, when two particles are entangled at the quantum level they display when disentangled identical behaviour at any distance up to and including infinity. 

You can see why Einstein called it ‘spooky’. Conventional science, though having proven quantum entanglement to be a universal constant (https://www.technologyreview.com/s/427174/einsteins-spooky-action-at-a-distance-paradox-older-than-thought/), had no idea how to explain it – until the simulation theory came along. In a digital simulation particles could indeed display the same behaviour at infinite distances because time and space do not matter: each individual quantum bit is located – as with a computer simulation – at exactly the same distance from the server. 

You can see why it might have begged Einstein. But did the great man have a better alternative?

3. Einstein Got It Wrong: Get Over It

Even Einstein admitted that 'reality is merely an illusion, albeit a very persistent one' (http://www.brainyquote.com/quotes/quotes/a/alberteins100298.html) – an admission he himself had trouble escaping from. A genius who wrote four revolutionary papers in one year, Einstein spent thirty years of his life trying to come up with a universal theory of the universe, and admitted failure shortly before his death in 1955.

 What is of note is that Einstein deplored the idea of quantum physics, and in part wanted to use his universal theory to finally lay all this quantum mechanics nonsense to rest while settling a long-running rivalry with fellow physicist, Neils Bohr (http://phys.org/news/2012-03-physicist-einstein-beaten-bohr-famous.html) in the process, but was unable to do so. 

The fact that practically everything we take for granted in the modern world, from the modern computer to GPS satellites to mobile phone technology, relies on principles of quantum physics (http://www.forbes.com/sites/chadorzel/2015/08/13/what-has-quantum-mechanics-ever-done-for-us/#6b3975236759) cuts the simulation idea a great deal of slack. We all benefit from its application, even if we’re not quite prepared to accept its counter-intuitive absurdness. Yet. Cue “The Twilight Zone” theme music…

Counter-intuitive it may be, but is it a better theory of the universe? 

2. The Simulation Theory is a Better Theory of the Universe

The universe currently only makes sense from the perspective of the simulation theory (http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/227126-neil-degrasse-tyson-says-its-very-likely-the-universe-is-a-simulation): certain things that conventional physics cannot explain are suddenly explainable. 

For example, the Big Bang is a perfect analogy of the information explosion when a computer powers up (https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/0801/0801.0337.pdf). The notion that light speed is restricted to a specific constant is compatible with the limitations of a program running on digital circuits with a finite capacity. The understanding that within the laws of science the development of life would not have been possible unless many fundamental values – such as the ratio of the masses of the proton and the electron – were not so finely adjusted is consistent with an external tinkerer. 

All of these anomalies fold neatly into an idealist digital view of the universe in which we reside, not a materialist view.   

So if the universe doesn’t technically exist… then do you?

1. Hold The Heart Attacks: It Does Not Mean ‘You’ Do Not Exist 

With the volume of the above evidence weighing in favour of a simulated universe, it is easy to lose all hope and resign yourself to simply being an AI avatar with no free will; a puppet of a post-human race. But this is not what science is showing us: look carefully – it is quite the opposite. 

Prepare for this mind-bender: if our consciousness determines reality then we are not a product of this reality: we created it – not the other way round. This means our consciousness is external to 'our' reality (http://www.naturalnews.com/038985_universe_simulation_intelligent_design.html) – which would explain why no evidence of the consciousness can be found in the physical brain. 

Look at it another way: in a similar way that an elf in 'World of Warcraft' obeys the player’s consciousness, so does the avatar we inhabit – our bodies and minds – as well as the existence we live in. The notion that reality is only called into existence when we interact with it, for example, is identical to the processes of a computer simulation, further underscoring this notion. 

So take heart: the upshot of this neat line of logic, which is now backed by hard scientific evidence, is that we do indeed possess free will and are not simply shackled to the physical form we currently occupy. In short, we are not a finite product of the reality we perceive around us. Einstein’s notion of reality as a ‘persistent illusion’ has been proven correct. And science in tandem with philosophy has freed us from its limitations. 

Determinism is dead, and idealism rules! Who’d have thought?
posts.title: 10 Hard-Science Arguments That Prove You are an Avatar

posts.text:
Imagine what conclusions an extraterrestrial being making first contact with Miley Cyrus on a Californian highway would draw about intelligent life on Earth. 

The pop star revealed details of a close encounter of the peak Miley kind she once had while traveling through Southern California with a friend. 

The “Wrecking Ball” singer claims to have been “chased down” by a UFO. 

Or, she admitted, perhaps it was the “weed wax” she had bought (and sampled) from a “guy in a van” prior to the alleged ET incident.

In an interview with designer Rick Owens in Interview magazine, Cyrus recalled the experience in vivid detail. 

Cyrus said: “I was driving through San Bernardino with my friend, and I got chased down by some sort of UFO. I’m pretty sure about what I saw, but I’d also bought weed wax from a guy in a van in front of a taco shop, so it could have been the weed wax.” 

“The best way to describe it is a flying snowplow. It had this big plow in the front of it and was glowing yellow. I did see it flying, and my friend saw it, too.”

Cyrus claims that the most disturbing part of the incident was when she locked eyes with the being helming the UFO. 

“I didn’t feel threatened at all, actually, but I did see a being sitting in the front of the flying object. It looked at me and we made eye contact, and I think that’s what really shook me, looking into the eyes of something that I couldn’t quite wrap my head around,” she said. 

“I was shaken for, like, five days. It fucked me up. I couldn’t really look at the sky the same. I thought they might come back.”

As for her thoughts regarding intelligent life beyond Earth, the “Midnight Sky” singersaid that believing humans to be the only intelligent beings in the universe is a “form of narcissism.” 

Disney Channel alums, it seems, have quite an extraterrestrial fan base, with Demi Lovato also recently sharing that she had made contact with extraterrestrial beings.
posts.title: Miley Cyrus 'Chased Down' By UFO… Or Maybe It Was The'Weed Wax'

posts.text:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Our voyage into this history begins, naturally, where any Crypto journey would: Purchasing Bitcoin.  At this point in my journey, I had already taken a deep dive though the Dark Web.  I’m sure you’ve all had your own similar personal experiences, so, we’ll move past that.  The Dark Web captured my heart as a young Cybersecurity student, both in technology and feel of adventure.  After reading some articles and finding an online guide, I had decided to make a purchase on The Silk Road (ep. 2).

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


2011


Let’s get into the purchase process. Options for purchase and documentation thereof was highly limited.  As a newcomer that was afraid of exchanges, I decided to do a deep dive into Bitcointalk forums and find a potential seller there.  


Bitcointalk had a primitive system set up.  Certain community members had built up reputations as escrow holders between buyer and seller.  Their motivation came through on taking a percentage fee of each transaction.  There were some obvious pitfalls in this through impersonation, but my only bout with that was quickly resolved by messaging the owner of the right account to confirm identity.  Having a reliable escrow facilitator really took the stress off of my purchase.  I can’t quite remember what my first wallet was (maybe electrum?). I used MoneyPak cards bought with cash each time.  Paranoia ran rampant on my fear of losing anonymity back then.  The only reason anyone had to buy Bitcoin back then was online gambling (ep. 3) or nefarious purchases. In the end, I managed to avoid scams and had this new technology sitting in my local wallet after a monumental  effort. My first and second purchases went surprisingly well with the guidance of escrow users!


Anecdote:  Bitcoin was right around $2.50 for my first transaction.  This doesn’t necessarily keep me up at night, but you’ll see later that my time in cryptocurrency gambling certainly haunts me!  I never took into account price movement back then.  My method of purchase was always fully executed within a few hours max, and items/services purchased were pegged to USD. Price awareness came later down the line after I shifted to an (amateur) investor mindset.

2012


Bitcoin didn’t feel real to me and I didn’t exactly understand the underlying process of what was happening.  My local wallet interface struck me as a game currency that broke out of its system and landed in a poorly-made UI.  Wallets didn’t improve for a long time, but means of purchase had a makeover shortly after my efforts in 2011.  Two life savers came in: Bitinstant(freshly discovered by me and not having Coinapult) and Localbitcoins. 


(If you’ve ever heard of Eric Vorhees or Charlie Shrem, this is where they rose to power.  Vorhees being the founder of Coinapult and Shrem Bitinstant. I’ll probably cover Shrem and some  other experiences in a tbd episode) 


Bitinstant was the best means to buy Bitcoin, in my opinion.  I did this a handful of times while going through my Freshman year of college. To be honest, that’s all a little hazy in memory to me.  I’ll try to cover it as correctly as memory serves for you.


First, I’d fill out an order on bitinstant.com that demanded a “pay from”, “pay to”, wallet address, and amount. The “pay from” was almost always Western Union (Walmart).  Providing some fake info in the personal information fields made you almost fully anonymous. Believe it or not, Western Union used to be one of the greatest institutional hurdles on Bitcoin’s path to a legitimate means of transaction.  Western Union was still essential in obtaining coins back then.  A caveat purchase is that there was nobody calculating your transaction fees and the price would move %10-30 on a regular day.  I would always pad my transactions with at least $30 extra to account for fees and price volatility.  Globally, everything purchased in Bitcoin had to meet a USD price.  Units of Bitcoin were considered even less useful for measurement of purchasing power back then than they are now.  


My memory isn’t clear on where Coinapult came in or what piece that even was in the process, but I remember that Moneygram payments in the early days were all made to ZipZap, a CA based company.  After filling out your Bitinstant, it would be the point in the process where you take a picture of your ZipZap sheet, go to Walmart, fill out a Western Union MoneyGram to ZipZap, pay with cash, fear that the government saw you on Walmart’s cameras, and wait for your transaction to go through so that funds could be sent to your wallet.  Bitinstant transactions always went smoothly for me, although even more paranoia was triggered through having to fill out physical paperwork and go through legitimate companies.  This process was much cleaner and safer than buying GreenPaks.  Forum escrow agents had been somewhat phased out by this new purchase process.  Anyone that was left quickly moved over to Localbitcoins. 


Localbitcoins was my favorite means of purchase.  It felt like there was no way of identifying the buying party with no paper trail. I became decent friends with (literally) my local source of Bitcoins.  Before it was highly monitored, it was one of the most pleasurable experiences that you could have.  My local Bitcoin seller was the informational bridge that led me into exchanges. He pointed me directly to BTC-e (ep. 4?).  Localbitcoins still exists today and i’m sure you could look up the actual process if you like. You pick your seller, set up a meeting, and each party brings private codes.  In my first transaction, I wasn’t sure what my seller looked like, so I grabbed a coffee while I texted him.  It turned out that he was the cyberpunk-looking guy in the corner of the room with an abundance of laptop stickers. The only other thing i’ll cover on the subject of Localbitcoins is that it was targeted long before authorities got involved with tracking sellers/buyers for tax purposes.  Sellers that established themselves within a community (like mine) were targeted because they left public places like Startbucks late at night with backpacks full of cash from a day’s worth of selling.  There have been many pitfalls for LocalBitcoins sellers throughout crypto history.  It’s a pity because the experience is so enjoyable.


By mid 2012, I was probably paying between $10-20 per Bitcoin. My classes were starting to cover cryptography, I was using Silk Road and participating in their community regularly, gambling on Seals With Clubs (ep. 3), had entered the vast world of altcoin exchanges, and had established myself Crypto Twitter/IRC.  I’ll go into greater detail on each of these as we continue to cover the year 2012.  I'm finding more and more areas that i'd like to cover, so you could see this series stick around for a while!


I’ve tried to focus on the purchase process and some orbiting details, but let me know if you want to know more on any subject that isn’t marked to be covered in later episodes.  I'd say this is the only "boring part" of the series. Any edits I make on this as I improve my general writing skills (or I run into random memory-jogging instances) will result in a new iteration of this post.  I'll be sure to keep a running note of what the most current versions of each episode are. Lastly, I'll have to make a general styling template for this to be prettier/more legible.


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Feel free to tweet me your thoughts/suggestions!

Thank you to Decentr and any readers for providing me an outlet!


-Fibrated (@Fibrated on Twitter)
posts.title: Behind the Blockchain: Purchasing Bitcoin in the Early 2010s

posts.text:
Received wisdom says that we lose muscle; our metabolism slows; and we generally go down a slippery slope that leads to death as soon as we hit our 30th birthday.

This is not entirely the case. By continuing to exercise as you get older you will lower your risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, stroke, diabetes, obesity, chronic back pain and osteoporosis helping you to stay fit and healthy with age. Here are three ways to acheive this:

1) Resistance Training

The vast majority of any muscular losses can be halted.  Muscle mass can be regained through structured resistance training.

Two total body resistance training sessions per week will help you keep your existing muscle mass and if you follow the principle of progressive load and consume enough calories, you can even substantially increase your muscle mass.

2) Mobility and Flexibility

Invest more time in improving your mobility and flexibility – otherwise you risk losing your range of movement as the years pass. While yoga isn't for everyone, a short daily mobility drill only takes five minutes and is an excellent way to start the day, allowing you to kickstart your body after a night's sleep. It will also give you longevity in your training, helping to stall issues such as poor posture, neck and lower back pain.

3) Cardio

Cardio will help you burn calories, raise your metabolism and keep your heart functioning well.

I recommend a mixture of low and high intensity cardio each week.

Low intensity activities will help you shed fat while also cultivating an active lifestyle that will hopefully establish habits you will carry on through your later years.

When exercising at a low intensity you're aiming to train at a specific heart rate – somewhere around the 105-120 beats per minute band, which is the zone where your body burns fat for energy.

Low Intensity Cardio Exercises

Try activities such as walking, cycling, dancing and swimming. The benefits of swimming are numerous: it improves your coordination, enhances your cardio system, aids fat loss, and gives you a top-to-toe stretch while you're at it. There's also the all-important low-to-no impact element: because you're not pounding the floor, your muscles and joints will thank you the next morning.

High intensity cardio should be done once or twice per week to help stimulate your metabolism and keep your high output fitness levels maintained.

Rest and listen to your body

Finally, as you age, one of the more important considerations is that whilst you can still perform at a very high level, you’ll notice that recovery takes a little longer. Hormone levels change a little and the joints have a little more wear and tear on them. This just means that you need to take that extra rest day between training sessions. When needed, listen to your body.
posts.title: Top 3 Tips to Stay Fit as You Age

posts.text:
Understanding and addressing the reasons why you’re not losing weight is a great way to kick-start shedding those unwanted pounds.

Those who are committed to their health and fitness realise that weight loss and maintenance is an ongoing process—if this process doesn't necessarily happen as quickly as you might like, there may be underlying contributing factors you can address. While understanding that a healthy weight loss regimen takes time as well as persistence, these underlying reasons are worth considering in order that you can better gauge your progress.

For example, even if you're committed to a regular workout, it may be that your calorie burn is insufficient to show any real progress. Perhaps you’re workout is sufficient to burn the requisite calories required for you to lose weight, but you may have an underlying medical condition that is working against your efforts to shed those unwanted pounds.

There are many factors that influence your ability to lose weight, some of them obvious and others that you may not have considered. In this three-part dpost we’ll have a look at some of the obvious and not so obvious reasons, and the science behind them. 

Reason 3: Losing Sleep

Weight gain can result from a lack of sleep. A study undertaken in 2006 discovered that women who slept seven hours at night were far less likely to gain weight than those who slept were five hours a night. The researchers in charge of the study speculate that:

  • The mental and physical dislocation caused by losing sleep may contribute to making you feel hungry despite the fact that you are not.

  • Sleep deprivation may adversely affect the secretion of a key hormone that regulates appetite – cortisol – perhaps contributing to feelings of a lack of satiation, even if you have recently eaten. 

  • The tiredness caused as a result of sleep deprivation may make you more lethargic, saucing you to skip regular exercise, indulging in sedentary activities instead. 

The physical effects of how losing sleep may affect weight loss also have a psychological dimension as well.

Sleep deprivation can contribute to a range of mood swings the can demotivate you as regards making healthy food choices and sticking to a healthy exercise routine: symptoms of these mood swings can manifest themselves as crankiness, confusion, irritability, and can even mild bouts of depression. Such mood swings can also alter your perception of body image, further demotivating you on the road to losing weight.

Maintaining regular sleeping patterns by going to bed and getting up at the same time every day, avoiding caffeine and other stimulants several hours before you go to bed, and other subtle diet and lifestyle changes can in turn help improve the sleep you get and contribute to your overall health and fitness.

Reason 2: Feeling Stressed

Constant stress, whether at work or at home, is well known to contribute to a number of health problems, from relatively minor to serious: the inability to lose weight, or even gain weight, is one of these problems. The following outline just a few of the many ways stress can affect your ability to lose weight as part of a healthy exercise and weight loss program.

  • Experiencing mild to severe cravings: When stress or unhappiness kicks in, it is common from many people to retreat into the solace of "comfort foods" – “comforting” due to their high sugar and fat content.

  • Raising the level of cortisol in your system: In a similar way to sleep deprivation, the production f cortisol increases in line with increased stress. This has the unwanted affect of increasing appetite while at the same time triggering the storage of extra abdominal fat, makin it very difficult to lose weight.

  • Encouraging you to regularly skip workouts: When facing a regular workout, feelings of fatigue and stress, or generally feeling down overall, can reduce the desire to exercise effectively, if at all.

Stress tends to creep up on us slowly. Taking time out during the day, however brief, to consciously self-assess stress levels is a good way to gauge whether you have chronic stress, and do something about it. Breathing exercises, gentle exercise, and even mindful meditation are great ways to bring a sense of calm to your life, and hence help lower your overall tension levels while reducing emotional eating.

Chronic stress is not necessarily something everyone can solve on their own. Talking with a doctor or a referral to a counselor can help you manage stress by together identifying your stressors and formulating a strategy to deal with them in a holistic manner.

Reason 1: Eating Too Much

This one may seem almost too obvious to mention. But the very fact that it seems “obvious” has been shown to be one of the reason why many people overlook it when trying to lose weight, with many assuming they are already “watching what they eat”. 

In practice, unless you're actively tracking and recording your calories each day, research has shown that the majority of people are actually getting a larger intake of calories than they think. Due to such factors as larger portion sizes when we go out to eat and snacking in between meals it is very easy to underestimate how much we actually consume. 

A study published in JAMA in 2009 discovered that research participants, when presented with high-calorific foods and asked to estimate the calorie content, underestimated the calorie count in these foods nearly 100% of the time.


For example, research participants were asked to assess the calorie content of chicken fajitas and fettuccine Alfredo at a restaurant. Participant feedback that accompanied their estimates made it clear that they assumed these choices were “healthy options”, and so the participants underestimated the calorie count of these dishes by 463 to almost 1000 calories.﻿ 

 

Considering that calorie intake estimates range from 1,600 to 2,400 calories per day for adult women and 2,000 to 3,000 calories per day for adult men, with the low end of the range for sedentary individuals and the high end of the range for active individuals, this is a pretty big discrepancy – almost half our daily calorie intake requirements. This is a discrepancy that could easily promote weight gain while affecting overall weight loss goals.

 

This is significant for anyone wishing to lose weight. 

A key factor as regards any successful weight loss programme is how many calories you're burning versus how many calories you’re eating—this is known as the concept of calories in vs. calories out. 

Anyone wishing to lose weight needs to be wary of calorie intake in the course of their day as they make and consume meal choices, thus promoting a positive mental and emotional outlook while being empowered through the control taken over healthy eating, calorie intake and the eventual weight loss resulting.
posts.title: 3 Reasons You're Not Losing Weight

posts.text:
These 3 practical tips can help you make healthier choices while covering the basics of healthy eating.

The key to a healthy diet is to eat the right amount of calories for how active you are so that you balance the energy you consume with the energy you use.

The principle is strightforward: if you eat or drink more than your body needs, you'll put on weight because the energy you do not use is stored as fat. If you eat and drink too little, you'll lose weight.

To ensure your body is receiving all the nutrients it needs, you should also eat a wide range of foods to make sure you're getting a balanced diet.

It's recommended that men have around 2,500 calories a day (10,500 kilojoules). Women should have around 2,000 calories a day (8,400 kilojoules).

Most adults in the UK and the US are eating more calories than they need and should eat fewer calories.

1. Base your meals on higher fibre starchy carbohydrates

Starchy carbohydrates should make up just over a third of the food you eat. They include potatoes, bread, rice, pasta and cereals.

Choose higher fibre or wholegrain varieties, such as wholewheat pasta, brown rice or potatoes with their skins on.

They contain more fibre than white or refined starchy carbohydrates and can help you feel full for longer.

Try to include at least 1 starchy food with each main meal. Some people think starchy foods are fattening, but gram for gram the carbohydrate they contain provides fewer than half the calories of fat.

Keep an eye on the fats you add when you're cooking or serving these types of foods because that's what increases the calorie content – for example, oil on chips, butter on bread and creamy sauces on pasta.

2. Eat lots of fruit and veg

It's recommended that you eat at least 5 portions of a variety of fruit and veg every day. They can be fresh, frozen, canned, dried or juiced.

Getting your 5 A Day is easier than it sounds. Why not chop a banana over your breakfast cereal, or swap your usual mid-morning snack for a piece of fresh fruit?

A portion of fresh, canned or frozen fruit and vegetables is 80g. A portion of dried fruit (which should be kept to mealtimes) is 30g.

A 150ml glass of fruit juice, vegetable juice or smoothie also counts as 1 portion, but limit the amount you have to no more than 1 glass a day as these drinks are sugary and can damage your teeth.

3. Eat more fish, including a portion of oily fish

Fish is a good source of protein and contains many vitamins and minerals.

Aim to eat at least 2 portions of fish a week, including at least 1 portion of oily fish.

Oily fish are high in omega-3 fats, which may help prevent heart disease.

Oily fish include:

salmon
trout
herring
sardines
pilchards
mackerel

Non-oily fish include:

haddock
plaice
coley
cod
tuna
skate
hake

You can choose from fresh, frozen and canned, but remember that canned and smoked fish can be high in salt.

Most people should be eating more fish, but there are recommended limits for some types of fish.
posts.title: Top 3 Tips for Healthy Eating

posts.text:
There is no shortcut to a healthy state, no magic fruit that lets you hit your five-a-day target and no single exercise that gives you a shredded physique in minutes.

It takes time and effort to get in shape and stay in shape. But if you follow these tips you’ll be able to reap the benefits (and they are legion) with a little less struggle.

1. Mix Up Your Exercise

Variety is – cliché alert! – the spice of life, and many sports and activities support each other in ways you won’t realise until you try it. For example, strength training for your legs and core will make you a better runner, while those addicted to dumbbells will find Pilates works muscles they’d never even considered.

2. Adjust Targets On Trackers

If you invest in a fitness tracker, don’t just sit back and assume that following the preset targets will lead you to glory. Adjust the steps, active minutes and calorie targets regularly to build on your progress, or make them more realistic if you never get close and have started to ignore them. If you don’t engage with your fitness tech, you’ll quickly discard it.

3. Add In Short Bursts Of Activity

It’s the oldest quick fitness fix in the book: take the stairs not the escalator, or get off the bus a stop early and walk. Any activity is good activity, and will only encourage you to do more. And if you really want to up the ante, try sprinting up the stairs (safely now) each time you take them – a recent study found that short bursts of high-intensity stair-climbing can make a significant difference to your cardiorespiratory fitness.
posts.title: Top 3 Fitness Tips To improve Your Health

posts.text: If all of these events come true, the cost of DEC can grow very rapidly. In particular, the cryptocurrency will not get stuck at $0.26 in 2020. Experts believe that due to the functionality of Stellar services, as well as to good work with customers, the price of cryptocurrency will be around $0.03 by January 2020. The more companies will be able to join Stellar products, there will be more intensive growth.
